awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of LUMICKS C-Trap Ultra-High-Resolution Optical Tweezer System
awd_abstract_narration:
Optical tweezers use light to non-invasively manipulate tiny objects (typically smaller than can be seen with the naked eye) including cells, nanoparticles, and individual molecules. The ability to hold, move, and stretch microscale objects with nanometer precision while simultaneously measuring fluorescence signals enables new scientific discoveries in biology, chemistry, and engineering. The Lumicks C-Trap system is state-of-the art optical tweezer system will support advanced experiments by a variety of researchers including single-molecule manipulation, mechanical properties of proteins and lipid membranes, and the study of forces governing colloidal and polymer assemblies. The knowledge obtained from optical tweezer studies have the potential to impact applications of national interest, ranging from new therapeutics and clinical treatments for various diseases to advanced materials for energy and sustainability needs.  

Widescale adoption of optical tweezers has been limited due to the difficulty in constructing and maintaining a robust optical tweezer system that can correctly measure nanoscale forces. The objective of this MRI proposal is to acquire a Lumicks C-Trap to add optical tweezer capabilities to the shared research instrumentation facility at Rice University.  The Lumicks C-Trap is a user-friendly optical tweezer instrument that combines wide-field and total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy to provide state-of-the-art imaging with simultaneous single-molecule manipulation. Additionally, the Lumicks C-Trap incorporates a novel microfluidic accessory that streamlines workflow and enables experiments to be performed under laminar flow in a temperature-controlled environment. Proposed experiments include tracking cellular processes, measuring protein and polymer surface interactions, probing the mechanical properties of biological membranes, and designing novel colloidal molecules. With the Lumicks C-Trap system, researchers and students will be trained to make sensitive force measurements, probe single-molecules, and manipulate materials with nanoscale precision.  Acquisition of the C-Trap will advance the growing field of soft condensed matter and biophysical research at Rice University and lead to collaborative research with institutions in the greater Houston region, including the Texas Medical Center.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF MRI-funded project has significantly advanced research, education, and community engagement at Rice University and the Texas Medical Center through the acquisition of the LUMICKS C-Trap Optical Tweezers with TIRF (Total Internal Reflection Fluorescence) Microscopy. This state-of-the-art instrument has facilitated transformative research across multiple disciplines, enabling high-resolution studies in single-molecule correlative force spectroscopy, optical microscopy, cell mechanobiology, microrheology, and nanoparticle manipulation.

The LUMICKS C-Trap has been instrumental in advancing our understanding of critical biological and physical processes. Key research applications include studying DNA-protein and protein-protein interactions, detecting bioanalytes with unprecedented sensitivity, characterizing the viscoelastic properties of biopolymers and chemical reagents, and achieving label-free visualization of complex biopolymers and cellular structures. These investigations have profound implications for fields such as therapeutics, bioengineering, and material science, driving innovation and interdisciplinary collaboration.

The project fostered extensive partnerships with leading institutions, including MD Anderson Cancer Center, Baylor College of Medicine, the University of Houston, and the University of Colorado at Denver. These collaborations have enhanced the reach and impact of the research, supporting the development of novel techniques and applications in biophysics and nanotechnology.

In addition to advancing research, the project prioritized education and workforce development. Workshops, hands-on training sessions, and integration of single-molecule techniques into graduate-level biophysics courses have trained a diverse group of researchers, including graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and faculty members. These initiatives equipped participants with advanced experimental skills, promoting a culture of excellence in scientific inquiry.

The project also engaged undergraduate students and teachers through NSF REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) and RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) programs. Summer internships provided participants with valuable hands-on experience and professional development opportunities, including mentoring and the chance to present their work in academic settings. These activities cultivated a strong foundation in experimental learning, inspiring undergraduates to pursue careers in STEM fields and equipping educators to enhance science curricula in schools across the Houston area.

Outreach and dissemination efforts amplified the project’s impact beyond the immediate academic community. Findings and methodologies were shared through conferences, workshops, seminars, social media platforms, and partnerships with industry. This broad dissemination fostered a vibrant exchange of ideas, promoting interdisciplinary progress and driving applications in therapeutics, bioengineering, and material science.

In summary, the NSF MRI-funded project, anchored by the LUMICKS C-Trap Optical Tweezers with TIRF microscopy, has not only advanced cutting-edge research but also enriched educational experiences, strengthened community engagement, and fostered innovation across multiple disciplines. Through its far-reaching impact, the project exemplifies the transformative potential of integrating advanced instrumentation with collaborative research and education initiatives.
